Literature Review: Physical human-robot interaction (pHRI) has emerged as a crucial field of study in robotics, focusing on the development of systems that enable safe and effective communication between humans and robots through physical contact. This review explores the evolution of pHRI research, from its initial focus on hardware design to the current emphasis on algorithmic approaches that facilitate more natural and intuitive interactions.The early stages of pHRI research primarily concentrated on creating hardware that could safely interact with humans. Haddadin et al. (2009) pioneered the development of lightweight robot arms with integrated torque sensors, enabling safe physical interactions. Similarly, Albu-Schäffer et al. (2007) introduced the concept of soft robotics, which utilizes compliant materials and structures to enhance safety during human-robot interactions.As hardware capabilities improved, the focus shifted towards developing algorithms that could interpret and respond to physical interactions. Admittance control, an approach based on physical analogies, became a fundamental technique in pHRI. Ott et al. (2010) demonstrated the effectiveness of admittance control in enabling intuitive physical guidance of robot arms by human operators.The field has since progressed to more sophisticated algorithmic approaches that incorporate higher-level reasoning and multimodal communication channels. Dragan et al. (2013) introduced the concept of legibility in robot motion, showing how robots can communicate their intentions through their movements, thereby enhancing the predictability and naturalness of interactions.Recent advancements in machine learning have opened up new possibilities for pHRI. Nikolaidis et al. (2017) developed a framework for mutual adaptation in human-robot collaboration, where both the human and the robot learn to adjust their behavior based on their interactions. This approach represents a significant step towards more flexible and adaptive pHRI systems.The integration of multiple modalities in pHRI has also gained traction. Medina et al. (2016) explored the combination of haptic and visual feedback in shared control scenarios, demonstrating improved task performance and user satisfaction. Similarly, Kucukyilmaz et al. (2013) investigated the role of haptic cues in conveying a robot's confidence during collaborative tasks, highlighting the potential of multimodal communication in enhancing human-robot teamwork.As pHRI systems become more sophisticated, there is a growing interest in developing algorithms that can generalize across different tasks and contexts. Losey et al. (2018) proposed a learning-based approach for inferring human intent from physical interactions, which can be applied to various collaborative scenarios. This work exemplifies the trend towards more versatile and adaptable pHRI systems.The concept of emergent embodied dialogue, as mentioned in the abstract, represents a promising direction for future pHRI research. This approach aims to enable bidirectional, multimodal communication that can be learned through continuous interaction. Billard et al. (2016) laid the groundwork for this concept by exploring how robots can learn from human demonstrations and physical guidance, paving the way for more natural and intuitive human-robot collaboration.Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in the field of pHRI. One major hurdle is the development of algorithms that can effectively handle the inherent variability in human behavior and intentions. Additionally, ensuring the safety and reliability of pHRI systems in diverse and unpredictable environments continues to be a critical concern.In conclusion, the field of pHRI has evolved significantly from its initial focus on hardware design to the current emphasis on sophisticated algorithmic approaches. The integration of multiple modalities, the development of learning-based methods, and the pursuit of emergent embodied dialogue represent promising avenues for future research. As these technologies continue to advance, we can anticipate more natural, intuitive, and versatile human-robot interactions, ultimately leading to more effective collaboration between humans and robots in various domains.
